Situation1: Celebrate each other's achievements and milestones.
Situation2: They review project timelines casually, ensuring tasks are generally progressing.
Story: I stared at my phone, my sister’s message lighting up the screen: “Don’t forget dinner tonight! I can’t wait to celebrate my promotion with you.” Her excitement was contagious, and I knew how much this meant to her. As her sister, I was supposed to be there, cheering her on, making her feel special. But my laptop chimed with a reminder—project review meeting in thirty minutes. As the lead architect, I was expected to keep tabs on every detail, even if our reviews were usually informal. Lately, the project had been slipping, and my manager hinted that I needed to be more hands-on. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in. My sister’s happiness depended on my presence, but my team’s progress depended on my attention. I could feel my chest tighten, torn between the warmth of family and the cold logic of deadlines. I glanced at the clock, wishing I could split myself in two, knowing that whatever I chose, I’d be letting someone down.
